article: Fill Her Tank First The summer of 1975 I'd just graduated from college in Southern California and received a 1968 Ford Capri for a graduation present. I had my first job, in Los Angeles. One Sunday night, _ myself a very independent grown-up, I left my uncle's place in South Laguna after a visit, without _ to him that I had less than an _ of a tank of gas and no cash to buy _ on the way to L.A. I pulled onto the Pacific Coast Highway and watched the needle _ as I headed north. When I started running on fumes, I pulled into a gas station . There was no self-service at that time ; there were no credit cards, no ATMs. I begged the guy at the station. I _ write him a check for gas, I said, or I could sleep in my car and try to _ to a town with a bank the next morning. As he was informing me that I could sleep in my car but he'd have me _ , a station wagon pulled up to the next pump. The driver--- a thin, plain, middle-aged guy---overheard the tail end of my _ request. As the attendant went to serve him, he nodded at me. " Fill her tank first," he said. "Really?" I said. Hope _ . "Oh, thank you. Thank you. But please. I just need two dollars' _ . I just need to go home." "Fill it," he _ to the attendant. Then to me, "You will do the same one day, for someone else." I keep looking for that unlucky young person, _ to save her night on the road. Meanwhile, in case she never _ up, I try for other acts of random kindness. That _ driver is always at the pump a few feet away, _ the attendant to fill mine first.
